description: Fundamental physics concepts including laws of motion, energy, thermodynamics, and basic calculations
author: Bryan A. Spruk

entries.definition: Three fundamental laws describing the relationship between forces and motion

first_law.statement: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force

second_law.units: Force in Newtons (N), mass in kg, acceleration in m/s²

third_law.statement: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction
examples: rocket propulsion
walking
Car accelerating: F = ma, more force = more acceleration
Book on table: normal force balances gravity
Rocket launch: exhaust pushes down, rocket pushes up

entries.definition: Forms of energy and the principle of conservation of energy

value.conservation_law: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed
value.work_energy_theorem: Work done = change in kinetic energy, W = ΔKE
value.power: rate of doing work, P = W/t, units: Watts (W)

examples: Falling object: gravitational PE converts to KE
Car engine: chemical energy → thermal → kinetic
Light bulb: electrical energy → thermal + light

entries.definition: Study of heat, temperature, and energy transfer

laws.zeroth: thermal equilibrium - two systems in contact reach same temperature

key_concepts.heat: energy transfer due to temperature difference
key_concepts.specific_heat: energy needed to raise temperature of 1kg by 1°C

examples: Ice melting: absorbs heat, temperature stays constant
Engine: converts thermal energy to mechanical work
Refrigerator: moves heat from cold to hot region

entries.definition: Fundamental concepts of electric charge, current, voltage, and circuits

value.power: P = VI = I²R = V²/R, measured in Watts (W)

examples: Light bulb: converts electrical energy to light and heat
Battery: chemical energy → electrical energy
Resistor in series: total R = R1 + R2
Resistor in parallel: 1/R_total = 1/R1 + 1/R2

entries.definition: Properties of waves and electromagnetic radiation

light_properties.reflection: angle of incidence = angle of reflection
light_properties.refraction: light bends when entering different medium

examples: Sound waves: mechanical waves requiring medium
Light waves: electromagnetic, travel through vacuum
Rainbow: refraction and dispersion of sunlight
Mirrors: reflection of light

entries.definition: Study of atomic nuclei, radioactivity, and nuclear reactions

nuclear_reactions.fission: heavy nucleus splits into lighter nuclei
nuclear_reactions.fusion: light nuclei combine into heavier nucleus

examples: Uranium-235 fission: used in nuclear power plants
Hydrogen fusion: powers the sun
Carbon dating: uses radioactive decay of C-14
Medical imaging: uses radioactive tracers
